Based on the search results, I found several academic sources from educational institutions discussing Frank Herbert's Dune, including analysis of desert and water symbolism. Here are the key findings:

## Academic Analysis of Desert and Water Symbolism in Dune

The search revealed several scholarly works from .edu domains examining the symbolic elements of desert and water in Frank Herbert's Dune:

### Desert as Living Environment
The cinematic chronotope of the desert presented in the film, in contrast with that of classic epic movies such as Lawrence of Arabia (1962) by David Lean, exists as a living and immanent organism embodying an unresolved dense field of possible ethical experimentations. This analysis suggests the desert serves as more than mere backdrop - it functions as a dynamic force within the narrative.

### Water and Political Ecology
The political ecology of water shapes environments and human responses. Water also plays a prominent role in Science Fiction, either by its abundance or its absence. Academic work specifically titled "Waterless World. Political Ecology of Frank Herbert's Dune" examines how water scarcity drives the novel's political and social dynamics.

### Ecological Foundations
Dune was the first ecological science fiction novel written at a time when ecology was an emerging field of study; in fact, Frank Herbert helped popularize the term ecology and conveyed a sense of planetary awareness for the Earth itself. This establishes Herbert's work as pioneering in environmental literature.

### Religious and Symbolic Dimensions
One major spiritual similarity is, as the water of life brings unity to the Fremen, so does the blood of Jesus or the Holy Spirit. Academic analysis from Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University draws parallels between the water symbolism in Dune and Christian religious imagery.

### Chaos Theory and Ecological Patterns
This ecological motif is integrated into many of the other most prominent elements of the Dune Chronicles, what we might call their "overtones," through mutual connections to chaos-theory concepts and structures. DePauw University's analysis explores how ecological themes connect to broader narrative patterns in the series.

The search found substantial academic engagement with Dune's environmental and symbolic elements, particularly from California State University Fullerton (which houses Frank Herbert's papers), DePauw University, Colorado College, and Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, among others. These sources analyze the desert and water symbolism through various lenses including political ecology, religious studies, chaos theory, and film philosophy.
